title: 114_hr4943
content: The Act may be cited as the "Tribal Tax and Investment Reform Act of 2016". The Congress recognizes the unique legal and political relationship between the United States and Indian tribes, acknowledging tribes' authority to provide governmental programs, develop economies, and build infrastructure on reservation lands as permanent homes. The Constitution, Federal Court decisions, Executive orders, and other laws affirm that Indian tribes are sovereign governments. The United States Constitution and Federal laws recognize Indian tribes as sovereign governments with the authority to tax, operate like other governments, finance projects with bonds, and maintain tax exemptions. Tax parity for tribal governments aligns with Federal treaties acknowledging tribal sovereignty. Indian tribes face historic disadvantages in accessing capital for infrastructure and job creation, hindered by statutory restrictions on governance. Indian tribes are excluded from key provisions in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, resulting in unfair tax treatment and unequal enforcement authority. Congress has the authority to regulate commerce with Indian tribes to further tribal self-governance. Congress exercises its authority to regulate commerce with Indian tribes, furthering tribal self-governance and affirming the government-to-government relationship with tribes. Indian tribes are treated as states with respect to bond issuance. Indian tribal governments are treated as states for certain purposes, with special rules for tax-exempt bonds issued by them. The Secretary of the Treasury establishes a national bond volume cap based on tribal population estimates. The national bond volume cap is determined based on tribal population estimates and allocated among Indian tribal governments seeking an allocation. The national bond volume cap for Indian tribal governments is adjusted annually based on the cost of living provision. Essential governmental function requirements are repealed. The amendment applies to obligations issued in calendar years after the enactment of the Act. The amendment made by subsection (a) applies to obligations issued in calendar years after the enactment of the Act, while the repeals made by subsection (b) apply to transactions and obligations issued in calendar years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. Treatment of pension and employee benefit plans by tribal governments. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include expanding the definition of qualified public safety employee to include Indian tribes and modifying the definition of governmental plan. The definition of governmental plan under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is expanded to include plans established for employees by Indian tribal governments, subdivisions of tribal governments, or entities wholly owned under Federal, State, or tribal law. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 now includes plans established by Indian tribal governments, their subdivisions, or entities wholly owned under Federal, State, or tribal law. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 now includes plans established by Indian tribal governments, their subdivisions, or entities wholly owned under Federal, State, or tribal law. Amendments have been made to exempt governmental deferred compensation plans and grandfather certain deferred compensation plans for Indian tribal governments. Certain Tribal Government Plans established before the enactment date and maintained by Indian tribal governments, subdivisions, or entities wholly owned under Federal, State, or tribal law, in compliance with specific subsections, will be treated as plans established by eligible employers under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 include recognizing plans established for employees by Indian tribal governments as governmental plans. Amendments to ERISA now include plans for employees by Indian tribal governments as governmental plans. The term 'governmental plan' is expanded to include plans established by Indian tribal governments, subdivisions, agencies, or entities wholly owned or controlled by them. Amendments to ERISA now include plans for employees by Indian tribal governments as governmental plans. The term 'governmental plan' is expanded to include plans established by Indian tribal governments, subdivisions, agencies, or entities wholly owned or controlled by them. Section 206(d)(3)(B)(ii)(II) of the Act is amended to include "tribal" after "State". Section 4021(b) of the Act is also amended for conforming purposes. Amendments to ERISA now include plans for employees by Indian tribal governments as governmental plans. This expands the definition of 'governmental plan' to include plans established by Indian tribal governments, subdivisions, agencies, or entities wholly owned or controlled by them. Section 4021(b) of the Act is amended to include provisions for plans established by Indian tribal governments. Amendments to ERISA expand the definition of 'governmental plan' to include plans established by Indian tribal governments, subdivisions, agencies, or entities wholly owned or controlled by them. Section 4021(b)(2) of the Act is amended accordingly. The amendments to ERISA broaden the definition of 'governmental plan' to include plans established by Indian tribal governments or entities owned or controlled by them. The effective date for these changes is after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. Tribal foundations and charities treated like charities funded and controlled by governmental funders and sponsors. Section 170(b)(1)(A) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include Indian tribal governments as governmental units. Section 509(a) is also amended to include organizations described in paragraph (2) for certain supporting organizations. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include Indian tribal governments as governmental units and certain supporting organizations. The amendments apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act. Improving tribal child support enforcement agencies by granting access to federal parent locator service and tax refund offsets. Access to Federal Parent Locator Service and improving the collection of past-due child support from federal tax refunds for tribal child support enforcement agencies. The amendment to the Social Security Act allows Indian tribes and tribal organizations eligible for a grant under section 455(f) to improve the collection of past-due child support from federal tax refunds. The amendment allows Indian tribes and tribal organizations to collect past-due child support from federal tax refunds. The amendment recognizes Indian tribal governments for determining special needs under the adoption credit in the Internal Revenue Code. It allows them to collect past-due child support from federal tax refunds.
